entry.title: Combined summary - Transition to post-quantum
entry.summary: On the bitcoin-dev mailing list, Tim Ruffing proposed a scheme using hash commitments to secure transactions. The commitment requires users to commit to a transaction with a hash before revealing the full transaction details, preventing attackers from modifying the transaction. However, some members raised concerns about the practicality and security of the proposal. Tristan Hoy presented his research on post-quantum attacks on Bitcoin and options for mitigating them. Hoy identified that none of the recommended post-quantum DSAs are scalable, and committing to a specific post-quantum DSA would be premature as the field is rapidly advancing. Hoy proposed a strategy that serves as a secure means of transferring balances into a post-quantum DSA address space, even if ECDSA is fully compromised, without requiring changes to the Bitcoin protocol or total commitment to a specific post-quantum DSA.Regarding the commitment scheme proposed by Ruffing, it has the advantage over Adam Back's proposal that it can be used for any address type and does not rely on ECDSA specifically. The main issue with this approach is that anybody can flood the blockchain with commitments. A proactive measure is required, but there is no need to change something now already. Even if the proposal is enabled today, people are not forced to use it. As long as ECDSA and the other schemes we use today remain secure, people can and will continue to perform conventional transactions. Double-spending is excluded after the first step is confirmed, making the protocol secure against quantum attackers who want to steal the money.However, in a post-quantum world, the second "d" type transaction in Bitcoin is vulnerable to front-running and forgeable if an adversary capable of breaking ECDSA listens for these transactions. PQ DSA is required to prevent front-running, and no commit-reveal scheme will be secure without one. Moreover, rolling out solutions proposed by Hoy and Tristan will effectively double transaction volumes. Solutions 2 and 3 in his article modify the address generation process to solve this problem.In an email exchange between Natanael and Tim, a potential attack on Bitcoin's commitment scheme is discussed. The attack involves an adversary inserting their own malicious commitment and decommitment to block an honest user's transaction from confirming and make their own commitment and transaction. However, the miners will see two commitments but only one valid decommitment, which may have been sent by the attacker but still needs to be challenged. The decommitment is unique to the UTXO and does not depend on the commitment, so the attacker cannot send a different decommitment.Tristan Hoy proposed a solution that changes key generation only and will be implemented by wallet providers, but acknowledges that no recommended post-quantum DSAs are scalable and commitment to a specific post-quantum DSA now would be premature. Feedback on his proposal is appreciated. However, Tim Ruffing clarifies that the worst-case outcome is that ECDSA is broken before PQ addresses are rolled out, which requires a proactive measure deployed sooner rather than later.A proactive measure adopted now will bloat the blockchain and also double the effective confirmation time for all transactions between now and when PQ addresses are rolled out, which isn't likely to happen in the next 5 years. The commit step fixes the output script, while the decommit step of a two-step transaction does not specify the effects. The solution suggested by Tristan Hoy is one such proactive measure.Overall, various proposals have been made to improve the security of transactions and mitigate potential vulnerabilities, such as using hash commitments and post-quantum DSA algorithms. However, there are still concerns about the practicality and effectiveness of these proposals, and further research and discussion is needed to develop more secure solutions.
